Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If therefore it is penetrating into the inner margin of the anus nearby, then draw out the thread from that hole so that you insert your finger into the anus and draw out the end of the thread, and join together both ends: and tighten both, and let it remain for one or two days; and as much as the thread sinks into the flesh, tighten it well until those pieces of flesh which are between the two ends of the thread fall off; then treat the wound until it consolidates and heals. 
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	But if the opening of the fistula is not penetrating, then make it penetrate by any means prepared for you unless it is very deep. 
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	For it is not fitting for you to do that because of a tear, so as not to fall into it. 
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Then proceed with it as we said until it heals.
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	The shape of the speculum of a spine by which a fistula is split, whose curvature is very sharp and the other part is not sharp so that it does not fall into what is not necessary, as you see. 
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	On the suturing of hemorrhoids from which blood flows from their incision and treatment of fissures. 
Caput LXXXI.	Chapter LXXXI.
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are hemorrhoids according to two manners.  
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	For they are either within the anus similar to bladders of coals or plums, or as if they are grains of a grape. 
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	And from them there are small ones and large ones; and blood flows from them always, and it is one and there are many.
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	And they are outside the anus and at its extremities. 
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	But those which are outside the anus are according to most few in moisture from which runs clear water or a little blood with constant flow and they are according to the color of the body.
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	The treatment for that which is within the anus is to make the patient strain, and press until it comes out of the anus, and you see the hemorrhoid. 
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore suspend them with hooks; or hold them with your fingernail. 
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut them at their roots. 
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	But if hooks do not hold them because of their moisture and softness, then take them with a rough cloth or with a swab of double wool and draw them out with your fingers. 
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut them, and sprinkle some hot powders over them after the incision so that they stand in place of a cautery. 
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what preceded in the chapter on cauterization.  
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with the remaining treatment until they are healed. 
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	But if the anus does not yield to evacuation, then give the patient an enema in which there is a little bite so that it washes what is in the anus and yields to evacuation quickly when the patient strains. 
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	But if the hemorrhoids are external from the anus, then their matter is light and easy; and it is to take them with your fingernail or take them with a hook, and cut them. 
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with what we have said until they are healed.  
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And he who recoils from incision with iron, then it is necessary that you administer suture of them according to this manner. 
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take a twisted thread and insert it into a needle.  
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw out the hemorrhoid to above and make it penetrate with the needle at its root on one side; and twist the two ends of the thread at the lower part of the needle so that they are lateral; and tighten the hemorrhoid with a strong ligature.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then tie the thread and remove the needle. 
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the hemorrhoids and leave one out of them; nor suture it so that blood flows from it freely. 
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place upon the anus a cloth soaked in rose oil, or carrot, and put this upon the anus; and instruct the patient to rest. 
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then let him go until it falls off. 
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When therefore the bandages fall off, care for them with ointments, and other treatment, until they are healed.  
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	On the Care of Fissures 
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Very often they happen from the drying of feces, and constriction of nature. 
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	But when they become ancient, and medicine does not prevail in them: then it is necessary that you scrape them with the point of a Spatula, or with your fingernail, until they become moist, and the upper layer which prevents them from consolidating be removed from them. 
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for them until they consolidate as is necessary.  
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	But if they do not consolidate: then repeat them with a more vigorous reason than the first, until they bleed much, and are skinned; then care for them until they are healed.  
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	On the Care of Inverted and Non-Inverted Hemorrhoids, and Dry Bandages and Adhesions. 
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter Eighty-Two. 
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	Know that a hemorrhoid is nothing but a round node according to the color of the body, similar to the head of a nail: and it occurs throughout the body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and toes: and pain arises from them upon walking.  
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	It is therefore necessary that what is around the head of the nail be cut, and be held with forceps or a hook, and be eradicated from its root.
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then care for it; and if you wish cauterize it according to what preceded in its chapter. 
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	But from dry bandages one is a small eminence, rough, filtered, round above the surface of the body.  
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And they very often occur in the hands of children. 
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And its treatment is to extend it with a small instrument and cut it; or to tie it with silk thread; or with hair, until it falls off. 
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what has been said before with fire or with a sharp medicine; and now the inverted and non-inverted hairs are eradicated with an instrument that I will mention. 
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	However, a wart is also a small, thick eminence, filtered over the surface of the body, extending deep; and when it finds cold, it feels like an ant bite therein and happens throughout the body; and most of it occurs on the hands. 
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And its treatment is to take a cannula from a goose feather or a strong vulture feather; and place that cannula over the wart until the circle of the cannula contains its parts. 
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then revolve your hand with the cannula until you cut what is in the circumference of the wart; and place it deep into the flesh and eradicate the wart from its root. 
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, do this with an air or iron cannula according to this form. 
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the cannula be drawing upward, covered with a bandage so that its grasp on the finger and its own revolution are eased. 
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you wish, cauterize the wart according to what has been said before in the cauterization of hairs in the chapter on cautery. 
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	Concerning the forms of instruments which are administered for fistulas in diseases of the anus, and the resolution of the abdomen, and colic.  
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter 83. 
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	Sometimes the clyster is made of silver, or brass, or cast bronze, or hammered bronze. 
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And sometimes it is made from these instruments small and large according to those in which they are administered.
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	Therefore, that which is administered in the treatment of small children, let it be small; and those whose anuses are weak or painful, so also their clysters. 
Clistere magnum.	Large enema. 
Cistere paruum.	Small enema. 
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	Its tube, that is, the upper head in which the uterus is tied, should be wide according to this manner: and let it have a distinction so that the uterus is tied as you see, and its lower end which is inserted into the anus, should be deaf, that is, not open, smooth, very drawing to subtlety: and on one side of it there should be two holes, and on the other side one hole. 
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And let the width of the hole be according to the thickness of the rays, and a little thicker, and let the uterus in which the medicines are placed be from an animal's bladder: or from a sheepskin, which should be according to the shape of a small asofrati: whose root is one palm. 
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And let it be perforated with many holes as it revolves, and the space which is between each hole be the thickness of a finger.  
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into those holes a strong thread from raw silk, which should be from ten threads, or thereabouts, and join with it a uterus like an asofrati. 
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When therefore the uterus is placed in it, tighten at the head of the enema between two distinguishing constrictions strongly.  
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then enema with it. 
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the shape of the circle and the holes depicted here.  
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	But the quality of enematizing with it is: to fill the uterus, or bladder with medicine which has been heated according to the amount tolerated by the sick person: and be careful that it is not too hot, or too cold. 
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then let the sick person lie on his back, and raise his legs to a higher position: and put under him an inthaa, that is, a piece of leather on which people lie, or a linen cloth.  
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then smear the end of the enema with oil, or with egg white, or with fenugreek mucilage, or similar substances. 
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then insert it into the anus with ease. 
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then let the attendant grasp the clyster with both his hands at once and squeeze it forcefully until he evacuates everything that is in the clyster into the intestine. 
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then withdraw the clyster, and let the patient raise his legs to the wall. 
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If the medicine compels him to evacuate, then he should hold it in as long as he can. 
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps with it all night, it is better for his recovery.  
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if you clyster him in illnesses of abdominal distension and his evacuation is hastened, then repeat the clyster until he is healed. 
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	But if there are hemorrhoids or painful abscesses in the anus, then let the clyster be very fine and gentle, like those used for children. 
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of a fine clyster over which there should be a tight skin. 
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	On the Treatment of Head Wounds Without Fracture of the Bone. 
Caput LXXXIIII.	Chapter Eighty-Four.  
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already said in the division on the treatment of wounds what was fitting for the book, and I will say here their treatment with the hand and with medicines according to supplementation.  
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	Therefore, I say that wounds are diversified according to what causes them and according to the place on which it falls. 
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	The things by which wounds are made are often these, such as the throw of a stone: or a cut with a sword or knife; or a blow with a spear, wood, or arrow: and similar things from many objects. 
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	But wounds that are made according to the locations of the body are like a wound that falls on the head or neck or chest or abdomen or back; and similar ones from those limbs. 
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am going to relate the treatments of some wounds so as to establish that reasoning and rule for the rest of the wounds. 
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with simple wounds of the head: for the recollection of compound wounds will come at the beginning of the third chapter. 
Dico ergo.	Therefore, I say. 
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	Therefore, when a simple wound occurs on the head and there is no fracture of the bone, then consider whether it is from the throw of a stone or something similar, and has already broken only the skin, and the wound is large, and you fear an unfavorable outcome of a hot abscess: then hurry and immediately perform cephalic phlebotomy, and do not delay it; and draw out blood from him according to the amount of his strength. If there is nothing prohibiting phlebotomy, especially if the blood flowing from the wound is little. 
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy be from the opposite side of the wounded part.  
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the sick person beware of overeating, wine, and rich foods. 
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	But if something prohibits reduction, then let him reduce his food intake and not approach meats or wines.  
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And place over the wound, if a hot abscess occurs to him, cotton infused in rose oil alone, or with wine in which there is astringency. 
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	But if you are safe from a hot abscess, then place over the wound, if it is fresh with its own blood and has not been changed by the air, the powder which I will relate a little later: and if the air has already changed it, then place something on it as an ointment until it heals. 
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	But if the wound is large, or is from an incision of a sword and similar instruments: and the lips thereof do not come together by powders, then bring them together with suture, according to what I will relate in abdominal wounds about their sutures.  
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	But if the wound is already detached from the bone and hangs, and there is no retention of it except in a small suspender, then incise it. 
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then care for the wound with medicines and restore hard flesh in its place instead of skin, and instruct the sick person to nourish himself with foods that are dense, such as heads and cooked wheat, until it is like a pulse; and things similar to these. 
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find putrefaction in the skin, and it does not adhere to the bone, then cut out all the putrefied part and throw it away; then treat that. 
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	But if in these wounds there is an artery or vein from which blood flows and it is not severed by medication, then examine above the artery. 
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If therefore you find it not cut, then cut it with a scalpel or tie it off.  
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if necessity compels when that which we have said does not work, then cauterize it until the blood is severed.  
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	But if these wounds are small and simple, then the matter of them is easy, light so that you sprinkle this powder over them: because it hardens them before they change from air.  
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of Incarnating Powder. 
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Take one part frankincense, and two parts dragon's blood, and three parts quicklime; grind the whole very well, and sift it; and fill the wound with it and constrict it well with a bandage until it adheres to it well and clots with the blood. 
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then bind it on top with wool, and leave it alone, and do not loosen it while it remains so that it does not fester.  
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For medicine is not removed from it until it heals. 
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And sometimes lime alone does it when you do not have frankincense and dragon's blood present; and it also performs the same action in many large wounds, when it is fitting to put it on them and bandage them tightly, and they are recent wounds with their own blood which has not been changed by air.  
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	But if it has already been changed by the air with some alteration, especially when it is in summer time, then the application of this powder is not appropriate; therefore treat it with what we said so that you put some digestive ointments on them or apply poultices made from barley flour with water and honey on them until they discharge pus. 
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then let the rest be treated with care until they are healed. 
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	But if it should happen that there is a fracture in the bone with the wound, and it is small, then extract it with forceps; and I will now speak of the treatment of head fractures in what is to come. 
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Concerning wounds of the neck. 
Caput LXXXV.	Chapter Eighty-Five. 
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	But if a wound should happen in the neck, then there is no difference in its treatment and that of a simple head wound. 
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	But if a nerve or artery of the neck has already been cut, then if it is a nerve, there is nothing to be done except to apply treatment that promotes strong astringency, such as alum and saffron and those similar. 
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	Because they are harmful to nerves and constrict them. 
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	And do not put anything cold at all on the wound; because the substance of nerves is cold, and its continuation is with the brain, which is more sublime than other members: and let it be treated with medicines that are mild, such as lime slaked with sweet water repeatedly infused with oil or rose oil, and tutia when washed even with sweet water: and the remaining mineral stones, in this manner, and soft ointments.  
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	But if the wound is large, then administer a suture or bind its lips with powders. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is healed. 
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	But if the wound is deep or a sinus occurs in its lower part, in which pus has already collected, then pierce it in a deeper place. 
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	But if an artery has already been cut in the wound and its blood flow follows: then separate or cauterize it and tie it; or cauterize it, if necessity calls for it. 
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	But if the vertebrae of the throat or the whole throat have already fallen and the ligaments are unharmed: then bring the lips of the skin together with a suture over the canal of the throat, and do not touch the throat at all; rather equalize it and return it to its natural shape. 
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it with a decent ligature and let it alone for several days. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments which have astringency and drying properties until it heals. 
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	But if the wound has already made an impression on the bone, then examine it: then if there are bone fragments in it, extract them all, or as many as you can; and what is not prepared, leave it until the wound putrefies, and separates and its discharge is alleviated. 
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	But if the wound is recent, then sprinkle upon it the powder which I have described.  
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	But if bone appears to be seen in the wound and a fistula forms: then treat it with that of which its remembrance comes in its own chapter.  
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	Concerning a wound on the spatulas. 
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter Eighty-Six.  
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is a blow from a spear or knife and you see its depth, then consider. 
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	Therefore if windiness comes forth from the wound when a weak person breathes out from it, then know that the wound is mortal.  
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	But if it is not deep for him and is recent with its own blood: then do not put powder on it from the first hour, nor bind it up so that the blood is not retained in its depth and returns to the heart and kills the weak person; but put an attractive ointment on it and dissolve it twice a day.  
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	But if ointment is not present to you then put an old rag in the opening of the wound so that it absorbs what comes out of it from its humidity; and make the weak person sleep on the wound so that what gathers in it runs.  
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	But if three days or more have already passed since the wound and it does not happen to the weak person that there is a spasm nor bad trembling of the heart nor constriction in breathing, and you see its remaining dispositions are good: then know that the wound is safe.  
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Therefore treat it carefully with ointments and other care until it is healed. 
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	But if healing is delayed and it is always open, then know that a fistula has already formed. 
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Therefore treat it from its chapter. 
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from an incision by a sword or knife and it is simple on the surface of the chest or back, then treat it with what precedes from suture if it is large, or with powder if it is small. 
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if it has already made an impression on the bone and chips come out of it, then probe the wound and hasten to extract those chips if they are separate.  
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	But if they are not separate, then leave them until the wound festers, for extraction is alleviated then. 
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	But for the accidents of the remaining wounds on the other limbs, judgment in treatment is the same judgment that we have said.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Concerning wounds of the belly and the protrusion of intestines and their removal. 
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter 87.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	Disruption which happens to the belly is great, medium and small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	From a great one therefore sometimes intestines or a number of intestines protrude.  
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore insertion and suture of them is more urgent and difficult. 
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And even a small disruption is difficult in another way.  
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	It therefore follows that its reduction is more difficult if you do not hasten in inserting it back into its place immediately; because it swells, opens, and enlarges, therefore its entry becomes difficult.   
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Because of this, therefore a medium disruption is better: because reduction of the intestines with it is not difficult as it becomes in these two kinds.
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that suture of the belly is according to four methods. 
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two sutures are common and apply to the suture of the belly and the suture of other wounds of the body; and two other sutures specifically belong to the remaining wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	But they are more appropriate for suture of the abdomen and I will describe each one to you with explanation. 
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	Therefore I say that when a wound is small and something from the intestines protrudes from it and it is difficult to reduce it: then it is due to one of two methods. 
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the disruption as we said or because there is inflation in the intestine due to cold air. 
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When therefore it is so, it is necessary that you warm it so that you submerge a sponge or cloth dampened in lukewarm water alone. 
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or you boil in water rue and cyperus and spikenard and embrocate with it the intestine until the inflation is resolved. 
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	Sometimes wine in which there is astringency does it and it is better than water alone in resolving the inflation. 
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When therefore you see that the inflation has already been resolved then moisten the intestine with water in which marshmallow or mullein has been boiled. 
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For by that its entrance is eased when it is small. 
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	But if its return is excused after this treatment then make a small incision in the disruption with an instrument by which hemorrhoids are cut. 
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first treatment is better when prepared than incision and it is not necessary to resort to cutting after necessity and lack of instrument. 
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part of it be twisted and sharp and the other part not sharp and let its subtle end not be with the subtlety of a spatula but rather be a little duller and it is that which resembles a chisel as you see. 
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When therefore the wound is enlarged and the intestine enters then it is necessary that its reduction be according to its natural form in its own place if possible above it for it is better. 
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	But when the disruption is wide in the lower part of the abdomen then it is necessary that you make the sick person lie on his back and put his legs higher than his head. 
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the belly, then place its head and chest higher than its lower parts. 
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And similarly if there is a rupture in one of the two parts of the belly, then place your attention and consideration always on this, that the part in which the wound is be higher than the other part. 
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And thus it must be done in large wounds and in medium wounds. 
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But in small wounds, place it according to what is prepared for you. 
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make a pious minister present between your hands, who will hold the whole rupture with his hand and bring together its lips. 
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then uncover from it for him who follows a stitch after a stitch, and this is the way of a common single suture. 
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is necessary that you take a needle or a number of needles according to the size of the width of the wound. 
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then leave from the extremity of the rupture a length of a ring finger, that is, of a physician; and fix a needle beyond which you will insert thread into it at two extremities of skin with two extremities of the underlying tissue, until you make it penetrate from the other side, and you have now brought together the two extremities of skin and the two extremities of the underlying tissue, and four rows are made. 
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then tighten with double thread around the needle several times from both sides at once until two lips of the wound are brought together with decent joining.  
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then leave a length of a finger also and fix another needle in them; afterwards draw it with thread just as you did with the first needle. 
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Therefore do not cease doing this until you complete the constriction of the whole wound.  
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let the needles be medium between thickness and thinness; because thin needles penetrate flesh very quickly and thick ones are difficult to enter into skin. Therefore it must be that they are medium in thinness and thickness. 
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not necessary that the needle be fixed in two nearby extremities of the skin too much: so that the flesh does not quickly fall in, and the wound opens before its own consolidation, and they are not even elongated with the suture, so that the wound is not prevented from consolidating.  
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut the extremity of the needle, so that they do not injure the weak one in his sleep; and put little wads of cloths on every side, which hold the extremities of the needles; and let them remain until you know that the wound has already consolidated. 
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this kind of suture with needles is indeed more suitable in small wounds. 
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	Because it suffices in the suture of those, one needle, or two, or about that many.  
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	But the second suture is common, so that aggregates with a suture have four extremities: two extremities of skin, and two extremities of silk in one thread, with a needle in which is wrapped a thread equal in subtlety, and thickness.  
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have penetrated with the needle those four extremities, reduce the needle from the side from which you began the same way, so that the drawn thread falls from the upper part of the wound: so that it is a suture, like the suture of cloth with which cloths are tied, and put between every suture an amount equal to the thickness of a finger.  
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	But men know this suture. 
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this suture I sewed up my own wound which had happened to a man in his belly, who had been wounded with a knife, and the disruption of the wound was greater than one palm: and about two palms had come out from the intestines from the middle intestine, and the disruption was in the middle of the belly.  
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	I therefore returned it after his intestine stood outside the wound for 24 hours. 
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	The wound therefore consolidated in a space of about 15 days; and I looked after it, and it was healed; and he lived afterward for many years, engaged in his own affairs.  
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the physicians had judged that it would not heal. 
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And it was a wonder that I did not treat it with ointment. 
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	For I was in a place where neither ointment nor anything from medicines was found. 
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	I therefore placed an old shirt over the wound twice a day, and I diligently washed it with honey water until it was healed. 
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	But I will mention two proper kinds of suture according to the account of speech.  
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is, that you begin with a sharp suture: and you introduce the needle from the outer to the inner part. 
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When therefore the needle penetrates into the skin, and goes into the muscle according to the length and width of the whole body: let the end of the thread remain on the side in which you introduced the needle, and make it penetrate at the other end from the inner part to the outer part at the other extremity. 
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When therefore you have made it penetrate, then make it penetrate thus in the same extremity from the outer part to the inner: and let the end of the thread which is on this side remain, and make the needle penetrate into the other extremity from the inner part to the outer: and make it penetrate with your penetration that you make it penetrate into the thread at the extremity which is in its part, until it penetrates the whole. 
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then begin also from this same side and sew it with the end which is from the thread on the other side, and draw out the needle from the skin which it has penetrated.  
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then return it into that skin and sew the end of the thread which is on the other side with this end: and draw it out from the skin which is on its side, and do this vice versa one time, and another, until you have sewn all the outside according to that example. 
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the sum of this suture is that you sew it like the sutures of skinners who sew skins: so that you sew the thread once from one side with one end of the skin: and that you let it go again on the other side, until you complete it. 
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of suture proper, which Galen mentioned. 
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	His speech is recounted so that it should be done in a similar way as some physicians do, in such a manner that they bring every part to its corresponding matching counterpart by nature: and they apply the extremity of sifac to its other extremity, and the extremity of mirach to its other extremity. 
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And that is done according to what I tell you. 
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	You must fix the needle into the extremity of mirach nearest to you from the external part, and make it penetrate to the internal one in that alone: and let go of the two extremities of sifac. 
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then revolve the needle and make it penetrate from the external part to the internal one into the two extremities of sifac, namely on both sides. 
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then revolve both, and also make both penetrate from the internal one up to the external one, into the other two extremities of mirach, which are on the opposite side. 
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of suture is better than the common easy suture, and it is the suture of which previous mention was made. 
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This then is the speech of Galen also.  
Et dixerunt quidam.	And some said. 
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The suture of the abdomen is rectified with two needles.  
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	Which is, that you introduce one thread into both of them: and begin with the introduction of the needle, from that which is near you, and make it penetrate up to the other side, according to the suture of those who have equal skins. 
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when the disruption is in the middle of the abdomen, then its suture is more difficult than that of the other places of the abdomen. 
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	But judgment of treatment of a wound is judgment of other wounds.  
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	Which is, because when you obtain a fresh wound with its own blood, before the air alters it; and you reduce the intestines and fit them to themselves: then put powdered incarnatium on top of it. 
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	If the air has already changed the wound, then put some ointment upon it, which are present to you, until they make pus, and the filaments fall away, and the sutures become consolidated. 
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it as the treatment of other wounds, until it is healed. 
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if medicines are not present to you, then immediately put upon it, from the time it begins to discharge pus, old lint; and change it twice a day, as I have taught you, until it is healed. 
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need another medicine in many conditions when wounds are simple. 
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	But if you fear that the wound may extend to the principal limbs in injury, then it is necessary that you immerse soft wool in oil of tempered warmth, or in rose oil, and put it around the places which are between the thighs, and under the armpits.  
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	But if he feels pain, or punctures, or putrefaction in his bowels (for this often happens), then give him an enema with strong, black, warm wine; especially if the putrefaction has already reached the intestine and is about to penetrate as far as its cavity.  
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that what is from the large intestine is of easier healing, and what is from them of the subtle (intestine) is of more difficult healing. 
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	The intestine which is called Jejunum does not admit healing from a wound that occurs in it at all; and this is because of its multitude (of veins), which are large, and because of the subtlety of its body, and the nearness of its nature to nerves.  
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	But if that which proceeds from the wound is gushing forth, and you overtake it fresh, draw it back according to your reduction, by which you reduce the intestines equally.  
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if a space has passed it by and it has already become green, or black, then it is necessary that you bind it with thread above the place which has been stained from it, so that bleeding may not occur. 
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in the hip there are veins and arteries. 
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then incise what is beyond that ligament, and place two ends of a thread hanging from the lower part of the wound outside it: so that its attraction is relieved upon you, and its extraction at the hip, and the discharge of pus from the wound. 
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Recollection of a Wound That Occurs in the Intestine.  
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When disruption occurs in the intestine and it is small, then it is possible for it to be restored in some people; therefore because I have seen one who was wounded in his belly with a lance thrust, and the wound was from the right of the stomach, and the wound was old; and a fistula was made, and discharge came out of it, and flatulence.  
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	Therefore I applied treatment until I was not doubtful of its healing; nor did I cease to refine it until he was healed and the place consolidated. 
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw the place already consolidated, I feared for the sick man, that a bad accident might occur on his belly; and no bad accident befell him from it.  
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in better dispositions, eating and drinking, and becoming fat, and entering the bath, and exercising in his diets. 
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And already some experimenters have said that when a wound occurs in the intestine and it is small, then it must be ligated according to this method. 
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is, that you should take ants of large heads. 
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then bring together two lips of the wound, and place one ant from those that have an open mouth above the two lips of the wound. 
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When its head is therefore above them and it clenches its mouth, cut off its head; for it adheres and does not loosen. 
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another ant near the first one, and do not cease doing that with an ant after an ant according to the quantity of the whole wound. 
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce it and its wound. 
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For those heads remain attached within the intestine until the intestine is eaten and healed so that no harm befalls the sick man entirely. 
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And now it is possible that the intestine also be ligated with a fine thread which has been drawn out from an animal's intestine and attached to it after it is introduced into the needle. 
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is so that you take the extremity of this thread from the intestine and it be pared down greatly. 
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then bind at its end a fine linen thread wound around.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then introduce that thread into the needle and with it the intestine. 
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then reduce it into the rupture.  
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of suture with ants and intestine is not except according to the way of trust and hope. 
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that a wound which is large and wide especially if it is in one of the slender intestines then there is no remedy except refinement and there is altogether no healing of it.  
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	On the care of fistulas and fissures
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 88
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Know that every wound or abscess when it grows old and becomes ancient and turns into an ulcer and does not become firm and emits pus always and is not cut off then it is called universally a fistula no matter in what limb it may be and we call it zuchemen.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula indeed according to truth is a knotted filtration, hard, white with which there is no pain and which has the concavity of a bird's feather and on account of that some call it risati that is a feather. 
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And it is moist in certain hours which emits pus.  
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps the moisture splits open in certain hours. 
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And sometimes this moisture is much and sometimes little and it is thick and sometimes subtle.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I have already set forth above when I spoke of wounds that every sore which does not heal and flesh is not born in it is not due except to one of the novel causes
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	One of these is because of the small amount of blood in the body or because of its bad nature or because there is tough flesh between it and its lips preventing the birth of flesh or because it has much filth and dirtiness or because there is a putrid ulcer in it and the matter sent to it is of bad quality or because the medicine is unsuitable for its treatment or because there is a falling corruption in the region which is a kind of pestilence, or by the nature of the region as happens in Caesaraugusta in which digestion of illnesses is difficult and healing of abscesses is delayed by nature; or because it has one bone or a number of bones. 
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have already shown all these causes and their signs, and their treatments with medicines in division; and it is necessary here to make you know the treatment of Fistula and Zuken, which is done by the way of operation with the hand. 
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	Know therefore that a Fistula occurs in all the members of the body. 
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For from them are Fistulas which reach the large veins and arteries, or nerves, or sinews; or to the intestines, or to the bladder, or to one of the ribs; or to one of the vertebrae of the back, or to one of the joints composed in composition; such as the hand, and foot; and from them are those which go to the proximity of the principal member, and similar ones. 
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Which therefore of these Fistulas is according to this manner, is from illnesses difficult of healing, and does not receive a cure, and dealing with it is toil and ignorance. 
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	But if it is from Fistulas some of whose depth does not reach these places which I said; and you hope, and trust in its cure, and wish to come to the knowledge of it, then take a probe of iron, or steel, if the Fistula tends according to straightness, and inquire into it with it. 
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	But if there is crookedness in the Fistula, then investigate it with a probe of thin lead.  
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	Since lead is softened by the gentleness of its own body and bends around its crookedness. 
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	If a fistula has many openings, it is not possible for you to mark upon it with a probe. 
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore cleanse out from among its openings one opening.  
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the moisture with which you cleanse it flows towards the other openings and runs out of them. 
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then carefully inquire in what way it is possible for you to know that there is a bone or a nerve and whether the fistula's cavity is distant or near; or whether it is a single fistula which has many openings, and stand upon the whole of it with all your strength, inquiring of the sick person and finding pain by compression with your hand upon the place, and similar signs and causes arising from an abscess. 
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Therefore when you have stood upon all this true station, then go to the cure with confidence and consider then whether the fistula is near and apparent or in a healthy place far from a joint or a nerve or an artery or a vein or one of the places which I told you: then cut the fistula according to what has been previously said in my account and remove what is in it by filtration and corrupted flesh which arises at its opening from flesh or pus and similar things and treat it until it heals. 
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	But if the fistula is of distant depth and according to straightness: then it is necessary that you cut it deep as much as it is possible for you.  
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then clean it from all its corrupted flesh. 
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then apply linen wrapped in sharp medicines and introduce it up to the cavity of the fistula which you comprehended with an iron; do this several times until the sharp medicine corrodes all that remains in the cavity of the fistula from corruption. 
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with ointments which generate healthy flesh until it heals.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If it does not heal by this means, then cauterize it according to what we have described. 
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	Therefore if the cause of the fistula is bone and it is confirmed with you, then examine it yourself and cut it according to what I have told you; if nothing prevents you from a vein, or a nerve, or a principal member as we said. 
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If therefore bone is revealed to you and there is something of corruption and blackness in it, then scrape it out until all its corruption is removed. 
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which causes it to flesh, until it heals.  
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	But if it does not heal and emits pus as it was doing, then know that you have not reached the total eradication of the corruption.  
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore expose it again a second time and make a precise incision into it, and cleanse it with your utmost strength. 
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.  
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If therefore it heals, that is good; and if not, then know that the corruption is in a distant depth of the body, which you have not reached. 
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	Therefore there is no skill for you except to leave it to nature.  
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	But if the bone is small and corrupted and it is possible for you, draw it out with fine forceps that are suitable for it. 
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	But if there are many bones, then make a precise extraction of them all and do not leave any with your strength.  
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If something from the humors opposes you and there is no fear or error in their incision then cut into those humors and flesh if they are there and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	But if you do not have preparation for removing the bones from your time then place something over the wound so that it putrifies it and leave it until what is around those bones from flesh and humors putrefies. 
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And watch the wound so that it does not consolidate. 
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let the incision which you have made in your operation be constricted. 
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	If you are afraid, place on it a cotton wool soaked in sulfur ground with oil; or cotton wool soaked in Egyptian ointment, or some green ointments. 
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those humidities, to wit, putrefy and the bones are separated from them, their removal is eased, and their attraction as well. 
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	But if there is one large bone, such as the bone of the leg, or the bone of the hip, and similar to those, and that which has become corrupted from it is a large part; then scrape it with the last rasp until that blackness and corruption are removed. 
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the wound. 
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	But if what is corrupted in it is a large part, and the corruption has already reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to saw it, and to cut it all the way to the place where the corruption reaches; then care for it until it consolidates.  
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you a story of a man who had a wound on his leg: so that you may place it as an example and help for your operation. 
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	There was a young man of about thirty years of age to whom there came pain in his leg, from a cause which was moved upon him within the body, that is, from within, until the materials reached the leg, and it became inflamed with a large abscess; and he had no external cause. 
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	Time therefore was extended with him in error of the physicians until the abscess was opened and many materials gathered with it. 
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And his treatment was postponed until his leg became fistulous and many openings were made in it; which all emitted pus and the humidities of the body. 
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	Therefore a multitude of physicians treated him for about two years and there was no wise man in the art of the hand until I was called and I saw his leg and the materials which were flowing from those openings with great flow: even the whole body of the man had already wasted, and his color was yellow. 
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	Therefore insert a probe into one of the openings and let it reach the mouth. 
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the openings and found that they all led to one another from all parts of the leg. 
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.
