I hastened and cut above one of these openings until I exposed a part of bone; and I found it decayed, for it was corroded and blackened and putrid and pierced through until it reached the marrow. 
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	Therefore I sawed off what was revealed to me and prepared it from the decayed bone. 
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I determined that there was nothing in the bone except that corruption which I cut off and sawed.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I had now eradicated it. 
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I placed the restoration of the wound with strengthening medicines over a long space.  
Et non est consolidatum.	And it did not consolidate. 
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I probed and revealed above the bone a second time above the first revelation; and I found continuous corruption with the bone; and I sawed off what appeared to me also from that corruption. 
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I tried its restoration. 
Et non est restauratum.	And it was not restored.  
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	Therefore I revealed above it again and did not cease to cut the bone in pieces and try its restoration; and it was not restored until I cut out from the bone about a palm’s breadth and extracted it with its marrow. 
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with medicines and it consolidated quickly and healed; and this iteration was not necessary in its operation and section except because of the weakness of the sick man's constitution, and his lack of tolerance, and my fear for him concerning death; for he suffered from it every hour a bad fainting spell from excessive discharge.  
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was therefore healed with perfect healing; and flesh grew hard in the place of the bone, and his condition became good, and his strength returned; and he returned to his usual habits; and it did him no harm at all in walking. 
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	If however the prominent bone is already fractured in its place: it is necessary that you grasp it, in this manner: and it is: that you take a ligature and tighten it at the extremity of the prominent bone: and order someone to extend it upward: and place another ligature of thick wool above the first ligature. 
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind it above the flesh which is beneath the bone and extend its extremity so that you draw the flesh downwards and you expose the flesh over the place which you wish to saw so that the saw does not injure the flesh.  
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a plank beneath the bone below decently: for when you do this, it is not prevented that it may cut corrupt flesh. 
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that the saw be over the corrupt place a little while so that there not be corruption in the concavity of the bone and that it does not appear in its appearance to the sense and compel towards the saw of its own vice another.  
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	But if the bone is corrupt and is not prominent but rather continues its part with its part and the corruption is in its middle or in a part of it then expose all the flesh from all sides entirely. 
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place wood beneath. 
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Afterwards saw it from the first part where the corruption is until the saw continues from the other part and let the saw be according to the length from the corruption a little while as we said. 
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	But if the corruption is at the junction cut the corrupt junction itself and saw the bone where it continues from the other part.  
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if the corruption is in the continuation of two junctions then there is no skill there except abrasion. 
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	But if the corruption is in the bone of the hand or in the bone of the foot then the matter there is very difficult. 
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary that you inquire how the corruption appears to you.  
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And abrade it and cleanse it according to whatever arrangement is possible for you and with whatever skill it is rectified for you when it does not oppose Vein or Nerve. 
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that cutting instruments and saws for cutting these bones are many, according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and thinness, and size, and smallness, and hardness, and rarity. 
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that you prepare a suitable instrument for each type of operation.  
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations signify to you the kind of instrument you need, when you have long study. 
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the methods of this art, a testimony to the methods of illnesses; for then you will find by yourself what is suitable for it from instruments for every ailment. 
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I affirm to you in the last part of this chapter the number of instruments, which you put as examples on which you cut, and the testing by which you try on others. 
Forma Serrae.	The Form of a Saw. 
Forma alterius Serrae.	The Form of Another Saw. 
Forma Serrae alterius.	The Form of Another Saw. 
Forma Serrae alterius.	The Form of Another Saw.  
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of saw depicted, let it be well made. 
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its upper arch be sharp from iron; and its handle from boxwood, and let it be pyramidally well made. 
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The Form of a Scraper for Joints. 
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this scraper be according to the form of the head of a star-shaped key; and its points be according to the form of the points of an elischetfegi. 
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not suitable unless joint heads are rubbed with it when they are corrupted, or the mouth is wide and large. 
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The Form of a Larger Scraper.  
Forma medii Rasorii.	The Form of a Medium Scraper. 
Forma Rasorii lati.	The Form of a Wide Scraper. 
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The Form of a Scraper in Which There Is a Concavity.  
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The Form of Another Slender Scraper.  
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The Form of Another Scraper with a Curved End. 
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The shape of a small razor, of delicate thread. 
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The shape of a razor with which bones are cut. 
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Also the shape of a large razor. 
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to a spoke, and its end is like a saw; it is shown in many places for the reason of bones. 
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape of a razor which suits its purpose because it is perforated from bones. 
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Its end is triangular, and its points are sharp. 
Fit ex Indi.	It is made from India.  
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly, it is necessary that all which we have said be made from razors, and incisors, and saws. 
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On the incision of extremities, and the sawing of bones. 
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter Eighty-Nine.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	Limbs putrefy, either from an external or internal cause. 
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	Therefore when you have treated that corruption with medical care, and the treatment does not work; and you see the corruption entering into a limb which nothing repels: then it is necessary to cut that limb up to where the corruption reaches so that the weak person may be saved from death or from harm which is greater by the loss of a limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this happens to a limb is that it blackens until it seems burned; or it rots after the blackness: until that rot reaches what follows the limb, and spreads into the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore hasten with the incision of it, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from the sting of certain venomous creatures such as a sea scorpion, viper, weasel, and similar ones. 
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	Therefore if the corruption or sting is in the extremity of a finger, then cut the finger and do not give space to the corruption so that it advances up to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut it from the root of the forearm and do not give space to the corruption until it reaches the forearm. 
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it enters into it, then cut the arm at the elbow at its joint. 
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the corruption passes through and you see it around the elbow, then death is upon the sick man there.  
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And besides that in treatment, the quantity of virtue is to be administered. 
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And do the same with the foot, when the corruption enters into a toe, then cut off itself at one of the nodes; and if it seizes the arch of the foot, then cut off the entire foot. 
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it ascends to the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint.  
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	And if the corruption already reaches above the knee, then there is no skill in it except dismissal and leaving the sick man to death. 
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of cutting off a limb or binding it is to tie a ligature below the place where you wish to cut; and tie another ligature above the place.  
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let one attendant extend the lower ligature downward; and let another attendant extend the upper ligature upward. 
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligatures with a broad spatula until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut or bind it. 
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you put linen cloths on all sides, and the saw does not touch the healthy part;  and let the sick man have an added injury, and a warm poultice. 
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	But if internal bleeding occurs while you are operating, then cauterize the place quickly; or put some powders that staunch bleeding on top of it. 
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is completed.  
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable bandage for it and care for it until it heals. 
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that it happened to a man in his foot, the same thing that I tell you.  
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	Because blackness occurred in his foot, with a burn that resembles fire; and that corruption first happened to his toe until it began to spread to the whole foot. 
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore, a man recovered from himself after he saw the corruption fall into the member with its violence, which he found from pain and its burning; and it befell at the joint, and it was healed. 
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time passed him, that same corruption befell him in the index finger of his hand. 
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me then, and I tried to recover that excess with what I placed upon his hand from medicines after the purification of his body; and the excess was not repulsed, and it began to proceed into another finger: until the corruption began in the hand. 
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He therefore called upon me to cut his hand; and I did not want that, hoping from myself on the repulsion of that excess; and I also feared for him at the cutting of his hand death. 
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the virtue of the man was above the chance. 
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Afterward therefore he despaired of me, he returned to his land; and there reached me about him that he recovered, and he cut off his whole hand; and he was healed. 
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this account except that it may be a help upon that which falls of this kind of illness; and that there may be a meaning by which it is signified and according to which it is acted. 
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Concerning the cure of Sinuses, and the quality of clystering with medicines.  
Caput XC.	Chapter Ninety. 
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in certain fleshy members, and the space of the abscess extends, until it makes a collection of pus; then it breaks or is perforated, and what is in it goes out as pus, and a vacant place remains as if it were a vessel: and the skin which is upon it like a cloth that has already been thinned; and it does not reach its ultimate corruption, nor press into the mouth, nor into a nerve, nor into a ligament: it deserves to be called a Sinus, and not a Fistula. However, if the space of it extends until the corruption presses into any one of these members, then it is called a Fistula, or a zuken.  
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the care of it is, that you should cut all of its skin just as it turns over; and especially when it has been thinned and made like cloth; and you trust that it will not adhere to the place because of its corruption. 
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere and that last corruption does not follow from it; and if there is a thickness in the skin from flesh, then care for it with a clyster; and it is as if you were to direct it towards the Sinus. 
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that is emitted from it has a foul odor; then clysterize it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar and oil and ziniar, taking equal parts, are gathered in a vase; and they are decocted over fire until the medicine reddens; and comes to a thickness of honey. 
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what is necessary for you; and dissolve it with water and honey, and clysterize the Sinus with it; and constrict its orifice, and let the medicine remain in it for the quantity of two hours. 
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression; do that for so many days until the Sinus is cleansed and the stench is removed.  
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes it is clysterized with ash water when this medicine is not present for you; and it is as if you should take ash from vine wood, or ash from holly wood; and pour water over it. 
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then strain it and clysterize with it until you trust that the Sinus has already been washed.  
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	But if the weak person does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine nor ash water, then clysterize it with water and honey to which something already mixed from ground ziniar has been added.  
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or clysterize it with honey and wine mixed together, since honey's property is to cleanse and wash; and the wine makes the Sinus adhere, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in the wine. 
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this several times and are confident that the sinus corruption has already been removed, then give him an enema with something which promotes the growth of flesh in it. 
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And take diaphycon plaster and dissolve it with rose oil and astringent wine; or give him an enema with certain drugs and other ointments the properties of which I have written in the treatise on ointments. 
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	But if the sinus opening is narrow and will not admit the enema cannula, then widen it a little with an iron instrument; or place in it a licorice stick wrapped in Egyptian ointment or basil ointment until it is enlarged. 
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the opening is wide, then bring together its lips with sutures and allow from it a quantity into which the enema may enter without addition. 
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the opening from which pus flows is raised to a higher place, then dry it in a lower depression within it so that the pus may flow downwards; for when pus is confined in the depth of the sinus it prevents flesh from growing there.  
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But if it is not possible for you to dry the sinus around its lower part according to your desire, then try to prepare the limb with a preparation so that the pus flows from it easily according to what is prepared for you.  
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try that nothing of the pus be retained in it at all; and take consolidating medicines which are placed over a sign suitable for what you desire. 
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them on linen cloth.  
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such a quantity that it makes contact with the whole sinus. 
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps a hole directly into the sinus opening, somewhat larger than the sinus opening.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread some soothing ointments on another cloth according to the size of the hole and place it over the first cloth at a distance from the sinus opening so that the discharge of pus is relieved; and do not remove the large cloth except after several days at once. 
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is above the Sinus opening is he whom you remove every hour so that what collects in it from pus may exit; and so that you may know whether what flows from it is much or little; digested or undigested. 
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And again consider with this the place of the Sinus itself, whether its master feels pain in it or not, and whether there is an abscess in it or not.  
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	Therefore when your treatment proceeds thus and you see the matter which exits above the Sinus opening, then you know that the Sinus is already adhering or approaching adhesion; then loosen it in the morning or on the third day; and when you loosen the wound, then change another cloth and renew the ointment.  
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if thin pus flows from the Sinus after a long time, then do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, since there are some men who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds and there are some who act contrary to that. 
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if undigested pus flows from the Sinus after many days, then you know that the sinus is not adhering.  
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	Therefore if the adhesion of the Sinus is delayed and its matter is prolonged; then add to the drying medicines, as physicians truly do, so that the medicines are moist in their substance and dry in their power: such as dyafinicon ointment when an excess of addition from zegi is added to it. 
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And the last of all by which it is cured is that you take dyafinicon ointment and dissolve it with rose oil and pour old wine equal to it in substance over it. 
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then mix it well with it and use it.  
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now honey acts similarly to this action when you do not have dyafinicon ointment present; boil it until it thickens and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, aloe, and frankincense; grind the whole thing and sprinkle it over honey while it is on the fire. 
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then lay a linen cloth over it, and bind it tight over the Sinus; and anoint it with honey which you have boiled down until it is thick; and sprinkle powdered spices over it, and put a linen cloth over it, and bind it. 
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes long birthwort is administered with it, and roots of blue lily, and lily, and herb flour, and centaury. 
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simply or mixed, grind them, and sift them; and sprinkle them over the honey which I have described, and use it. 
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	And if the Sinus condition persists and does not heal with this treatment, then know that there is corruption deep within it; or it is already making an impression on the bones, or on the other hard members, or ligaments: then treat it with a treatment for Fistulas, according to what has been stated previously. 
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	On the treatment of whitlow and nail abrasion, and incision of an added finger, and sectioning.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 91.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Whitlow is an abscess which arises under the nail of the thumb of the hand or foot; and perhaps it arises in the other fingers. 
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	And therefore when the matter of it persists, and its cure is neglected, and it becomes inflamed with a hot abscess; or it corrupts and emits pus until it corrodes the root of the nail; and perhaps it corrupts the whole of it, and perhaps the corruption reaches the bone until it has a foul smell; and the end of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.  
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	Therefore when you treat it according to what we have said in the division, and your treatment does not take effect; then it is necessary that you cut with an instrument the whole excess which remains from the nail. 
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.  
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For cautery is very helpful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	But if the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the added empty parts of the nail already press the flesh inwards, and begin to prick it, and injure it: then it is necessary that you place a thin Radium under the angle of the nail which pricks the flesh, and push it upwards; and cut the flesh easily, and put over what remains of the flesh medicines that burn and corrode until all of it is removed. 
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments until it heals. 
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	But if corruption has already set in the bone, then it is necessary that you cut into that bone and extract it: for it will never heal as long as a corrupted bone remains within it. 
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	But if you see corrosion and corruption advancing into the finger, then cut it at one of its joints, according to what was previously mentioned about it. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals. 
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	But if it should happen that there is attrition or percussion to the nail, and there is a sharp pain in it, then it is necessary first to let blood from a weak person. 
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut the nail with a sharp spatulum in a transverse section from above downward.  
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful that the incision does not reach the flesh which is beneath the nail, for you will cause a very sharp pain through it and it will be a reason for added inflammation of the flesh in the place. 
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the area with that which soothes pains. 
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	Indeed the added finger which is born in some men's hands, perhaps it is all flesh; and perhaps there are bones in some of them; and perhaps a nail exists in it: and some of them are born at the root of the joint, or its origin is in some joints of the finger. 
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	That which is born in some joints of the finger does not move; and that which is born at the joint of the finger perhaps moves. 
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore the incision of that which is fleshy from them is easy.  
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, you should cut it at its root with a broad spatulum. 
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But the treatment of that whose origin is in the root of the joint is difficult.  
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore abstain from cutting it. 
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But in that which is born on the finger at the last joint, then it is necessary that you first cut its flesh with a round incision down to the bone. 
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then a saw with one of those saws suitable for it. 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals. 
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Moreover, consolidation which occurs between the fingers often happens either from the birth of man, that is, he is born with it, or from the consolidation of a wound, or from burning by fire, and similar things. 
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, it is necessary to cut that consolidation until the fingers return to their natural form.  
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place cloths between them soaked in rose oil so that they do not consolidate quickly and separate them, or place a thin sheet of lead between them until the place consolidates as it should.  
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if consolidation occurs with certain fingers and the palm, then cut that consolidation according to what is prepared and suits the shape of the limb. 
¶ De incisione Vitium.	On the Incision of a Vice.  
Caput XCII.	Chapter Ninety-Two. 
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Varices are veins enveloped, thick, full of superfluous melancholic humors which occur in many members of the body; and most often their outcome is in the legs, especially in the legs of those who travel and work, and carry things. 
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary that you administer exercise of the body from black bile several times with vigorous shaking.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then phlebotomy for the patient to those who are basil-like. 
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of them with iron is according to two methods. 
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they are cut and black blood is extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is that a vein is lifted and the whole thing is extracted. 
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section of it is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	First embrocate the leg with plenty of hot water until the thick fecal blood is resolved.  
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the leg of the sick person from the upper part of his hip down to the lower part of the knee with a bandage. 
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three with a wide incision. 
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then raise, that is, draw out the blood into your hand from the lower part of the leg, up to the top, and the phlebotomist must first weaken the one above. 
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut the vein all the way down until a quantity of blood comes out which you see to be sufficient and which the strength of the sick person can tolerate.  
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then tie it off and instruct him to abstain from foods that produce black bile; and repeat the evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full and it harms the sick person. 
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The raising of it is according to this method.  
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the leg of the sick person if there are many hairs on it. 
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse him in a bath or embrocate his leg with warm water until it reddens and the veins swell; or he should be exercised vigorously if there is no bath available for him until the limb is heated.  
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then cut the skin directly over the vein lengthwise; or at its end near the knee, or in its lower part near the heel. 
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with hooks and expose the vein from all sides until it appears to the senses; and at its appearance you will see it reddish towards a dark decline.  
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When therefore it comes out of the skin, you will see it white as if it were a cord. 
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then insert a cannula under it until it rises and comes out of the skin; suspend it with a blunt hook, gentle. 
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then cut another incision near that incision by three fingers. 
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then expose the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears. 
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then raise it with cannulas as you did and suspend it with another hook as you did first.  
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry another incision, or several incisions, if necessary. 
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate it and cut it with the last incision at the heel. 
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then draw it out to the incision which is above it. 
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do that until you draw it out from the incision which is above, or higher than all the incisions, until it comes out whole; then cut it.  
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you to be drawn out and elevated: then introduce a needle with a strong double thread, and tie it, and draw it out; or introduce a Radium under it, and revolve your hand in every direction until it comes out. 
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be careful that it is not cut. 
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it becomes difficult for you to elevate it greatly, and harm enters upon the weak part from it.  
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have drawn it all out: then place wool soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil over the place of the wound; and care for it until it is healed.  
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	But if the Vine is contracted, having a twist with an involution towards its parts, and it is not as we said according to straightness: then it is necessary that you split it over all the parts of its twist, and the places of its own involution.  
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with hooks until you raise it all; and be careful at your incision over it that you do not cut a vein, or wound it: for it will become difficult for you to raise, or draw it out.  
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore preserve your prudence. 
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The Form of the Falling Vine by which it is Healed. 
Forma Vncini caeci.	The Form of a Blind Vine.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It does not have a curvature like the other Hooks, nor an acute extremity, so that it would not wound a vein; and it is of a thick, gentle flexuousity; for if it were slender, it would cut the vein by its slenderness: but let its thickness be excessive, as we said. 
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the Extraction of a Leg Vein. 
Caput XCIII.	Chapter Ninety-Three. 
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in hot lands, such as Alizegi and the land of the Arabs, and in dry, hot lands of little tenderness, that is, those in which neither herb nor tree grows. 
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.  
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is indeed from putrefaction which occurs under the skin, just as serpents and ascaris worms occur within bodies, and worms generated between the skin and flesh. 
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein's event is that a violent inflammation occurs in the leg. 
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place blisters.  
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to come out from the place of that blistering, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal. 
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore its extremity appears from it, then it is necessary that you wrap upon it a piece of lead, whose weight is from one scruple to two scruples and bind it: and let the lead hang suspended from the leg. 
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever therefore anything exits from it to the outside, wrap that in the lead and bind it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it lengthens much, then cut a part of it and wrap up the remainder. 
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it out entirely before it comes out completely.  
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it, it contracts and enters into the flesh, and causes an abscess to occur, and putrefaction in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary that it be handled gently and extracted gradually until it comes out from its last part, and nothing remains of it in the body: and from this vein indeed, there exits in some men what is in its length five palms and ten.  
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has come to me that it came out of a man from twenty palms. 
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it should happen to you during your time of treatment: then introduce a ray into its hole, and perforate it with a long hole, with a body, until all that is in it from matter is evacuated: and administer putrefaction of the place with medicines for several days. 
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for it with treatment for abscesses. 
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And indeed this Vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the junction of the foot, or in the foot itself: and it happens to have many openings, and a branch comes out from every opening. 
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Care for it therefore as we said in the division, and with that which has been said before. 
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Concerning the incision over Worms generated under the skin, and it is called bovine disease. 
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter ninety-four. 
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is named in a certain land among us bovine disease: because it often happens to oxen, and there is a small worm, which is born between the skin and flesh. 
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it wanders in the whole body, ascending and descending: and it is shown to the senses during its locomotion of a limb to a limb, until it breaks wherever it breaks in the skin, and comes out. 
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the putrefaction of certain humors. 
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just as worms and snakes happen, that is, earthworms, and roundworms in the belly. 
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared from its malice.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it itself wanders in the body, and rises to the head, and reaches a place: then perhaps it opens in it, and comes out, and destroys the eye: and that happens very often.  
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore you wish to cure it, and extract it, then it is not done except at its locomotion, and appearance to the senses. 
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary to tie what is above it and what is below it with a strong ligature constriction. 
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it and extract it. 
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	But if it is buried deep in the flesh and you cannot find it, then place a cautery with fire upon the spot until it dies. 
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And the greater thing that is feared is its corruption, by which it corrupts the eye, as we said. 
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see that it has already reached the head near the eye, then constrict the eyebrow well above it. 
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut above it and extract it. 
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the weak person use cleansing of their body with medicines that dissolve foul and bad humors.  
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let them beware of foods that generate putrefaction. 
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	Concerning the cutting for the ailment Nakir. 
Caput XCV.	Chapter Ninety-Fifth.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This ailment is called Nakir in our land, and it is a pain that occurs in certain limbs, and then it changes from limb to limb. 
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have indeed already seen it, according to what I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was summoned to a weak woman in certain boils. 
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she exposed her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the brachioradialis muscle.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I remained for an hour, I saw one swelling advance with a focus, just as a worm advances, ascending to her shoulder faster than is possible: so that it was like molten silver when it runs from place to place. 
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore the pain receded from that place and became fixed in her shoulder. 
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour, and it ran through the rest of the body until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was revolving throughout her whole body, according to what I saw. 
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	Therefore I have been amazed at the speed of its transfer from limb to limb. 
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And for my part, before that I had never seen this ailment with my own eyes in such a manner. 
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I have seen many who find pain transferred from limb to limb: and I did not see it myself with my eyes as I saw it in this woman. 
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that this is so except because the woman was one of those from whom dry bodies with exposed veins are detected: therefore, this perceived windiness transferred here appears. 
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reasoning in those who are delicate and with moist bodies, hidden veins. 
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore you desire its cure and the patient feels that pain: then if it is apparent to you by eye, as we have said, then bind above it and below it quickly; and cut above it until that constricted windiness goes out; and cauterize the place. 
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	But if you do not see it with your own eyes: then treat it with shaking of the body and with that which expels windiness and drives them away with foul-smelling pills and pills from lizard's tail and similar things. 
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the Extraction of Arrows. 
Caput XCVI.	Chapter Ninety-Sixth. 
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are diversified according to their kinds and according to the places in which they fall from the body. 
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their diversity is indeed because some of them have large points and small ones: and concave ones and blunt ones. 
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And some of them have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And some of them which have tongues. 
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And some of them which have stars.  
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those indeed which are according to the limbs in which they fall are according to two manners. 
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For either the limbs are from the principal concave limbs such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and those similar to them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	Therefore, when it falls into any of these members, and the signs of death appear to you, which I will tell you after, then it is necessary that you avoid the extraction of that arrow from them, for death follows him in whom it is, in many dispositions. 
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these evil signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the member, then extract it, and care for the wound. 
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For among the signs of the brain when an arrow falls into it and penetrates the mouth and exits through the siphac which is above the brain, there is: because vehement soda and scotoma and vertigo and redness in the eyes and inflation and redness of the tongue and spasm and mixing of intellect and vomiting of cholera occur from it.  
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood exits from the nostrils or ears. 
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off and the voice is destroyed. 
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And humidity white like poultice exits from the place of the wound.  
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And a likeness of the aqueousness of flesh exits from it. 
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear to you, then abstain from treatment and extract the arrow if it does not exit.  
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	But the signs of an arrow when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left nipple and he feels as if it were fixed in a hard thing, not in a hollow thing. 
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps there is motion of the arrow similar to the motion of the pulse and black blood runs from the wound. 
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And coldness of the extremities follows, and cold sweat and fainting. 
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore that death descends without doubt.  
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow when it has wounded the lung is the exit of frothy blood from the wound and the vessels which follow the neck become inflamed and the color of the sick person changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out a great, deep spirit and seeks the attraction of cold air. 
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If an arrow should fall into the membrane which is in the chest: then it is near the small ribs: and there is great panting with vehement pain, with a sigh: and all the members of the shoulders are moved. 
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if an arrow should fall into the stomach, then perhaps some undigested food may come out of the wound. 
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow should fall into the belly, and is fixed therein: some dung may come out of the wound, or phlegm, or intestine which has already been ruptured. 
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore there is no hope in its cure, nor in the extraction of the arrow. 
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	And if an arrow should fall into the bladder, and urine should come out: and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is stronger on the weak: then know that it is mortal. 
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	But the remaining members, such as the face, and neck, and throat, and scapula, and armpit, and vertebrae of the back, and collarbone, and thigh, and leg, and those similar to these members are saved according to many dispositions: when the arrow does not find an artery, or a nerve: and the arrow is not poisoned.  
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I have seen concerning the being of these arrows, so that you may know through it concerning your cure. 
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Which is this: because to a certain man an arrow fell into the tear duct of his eye, at the root of the nose. 
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore I extracted it from him on the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and no harm befell his eye. 
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen to him in the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was already concealed, and I did not obtain anything from it except a small part of it, with which it adheres to its wood: and it was a large arrow from the arrows of Turkish bows, with soft iron, in which there are no ears. 
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	Therefore, the Jew was healed, and no evil accident befell his eye. 
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian. 
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabic arrow, and it is one that has ears. 
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	I therefore cut above it between two guideges, and it was already submerged in his throat. 
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I therefore proceeded carefully with it until I extracted it, and the Christian was healed.  
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man which had fallen into his belly, and we thought that he would die from it. 
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed him, and nothing changed in his condition, I cut above the arrow, I devised a plan with regard to it, and extracted it; and he was healed, and no evil accident befell him. 
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man to whom an arrow had fallen on his back, and the wound had become consolidated over it.  
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After therefore seven years had passed, the arrow came out at the root of his hip. 
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom an arrow had fallen in her belly, and the wound had become consolidated over it, and the arrow remained inside her: and nothing changed in her condition, and the woman did not find harm from it in any of her natural operations.  
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man to whom an arrow had fallen on his face: and the wound had become consolidated, and it remained, not finding him much pain; and similar things to these, many.  
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from a man of the King's princes, which had fallen to him in the middle of his nose, and it had already inclined towards the right side a little; and the whole arrow was concealed. 
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore called for his treatment three days after the fall of the arrow.  
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I therefore found the wound of the arrow very tight. 
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	Therefore I examined it with a delicate probe, and did not feel it; and he himself was finding the puncture and pain under his right ear. 
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	Therefore I hoped that it was that puncture from the end of the arrow. 
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore plastered the place with a plaster in which there was an attractive and digestive power, confident within myself that the place would become abscessed and the sign of the arrow would appear to me so that I could cut above it; and it did not happen in the place any accident indicating that the arrow had reached the place. 
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I therefore persisted with the plaster upon him for many days; and no accident happened, and the wound meanwhile became consolidated; and he remained weak from its extraction over a period of days, until he felt the arrow on a certain day inside his nose. 
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he related that to me. 
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I therefore put upon that wound a sharp, corrosive medicine for many days, until it opened; and when I probed it, I felt the slender extremity of the arrow adhering to the wood. 
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound through that sharp medicine until the extremity of the arrow appeared visibly to us; and it passed for me with him approximately a space of time of four months.  
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound had been enlarged and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it and move it, and it did not obey its exit; then I did not cease to refine and contrive upon it with ways of ingenuity until I began upon it on a certain day with forceps neatly made, according to which their form will come at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it. 
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound. 
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And physicians indeed judge that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.  
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I therefore restored it, and the wound became consolidated, and he was healed with complete health; nor did anything harm him at all. 
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of extracting certain arrows: so that you put that rule and meaning upon that which I did not say. 
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended with narration; nor does this book comprehend it, and a prudent craftsman compares with little upon much; and with that which is present, upon that which is absent; and he finds a new operation, and a new instrument at the descents of foreign matters of this art when they happen. 
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say, therefore, that arrows do not depart from the limbs in which they are fixed except according to two ways. 
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place from whence it entered.  
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or contrary to the other part. 
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which departs whence it entered, either is an arrow proceeding in a fleshy place; and it is attracted and departs. 
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	And if it does not obey to exit at the hour in which it falls: then it is necessary that you dismiss it for several days until the flesh which is in its circumference putrefies; and the attraction of it is relieved, and its exit. 
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is fixed in bone, and does not obey you to exit, then dismiss it also for several days; and repeat it with attraction and motion every day until it departs. 
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	And if it does not obey you to exit after days, then it is necessary that you pierce in the circumference of the arrow in the very bone from every part with a fine awl until the arrow is enlarged. 
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it and draw it out. 
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if an arrow is fixed in the bone of the head, and has already proceeded into one of the ventricles of the brain, and some of those accidents which I have said appear from weakness: then abstain from attracting the arrow, and dismiss it until its being equals after days.  
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the sifach, then death is not prolonged for him. 
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed except in the bone, and does not penetrate as far as the sinews, and it remains weak for several days and none of those accidents happen to him, then skill is needed in attracting the arrow and extracting it. 
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed firmly and does not obey your attraction, then apply a trepan around the arrow as I have described, then care for the place until it heals. 
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	But if the arrow is already hidden in the body and concealed from the senses, then seek it out with your hand. 
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with certain instruments that are suitable for its attraction. 
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	But if you cannot get hold of it because of the tightness of the wound and the length of the arrow deep inside, and there is neither a bone nor a nerve nor a vein there, then cut above it until the wound is enlarged and it is possible to extract the arrow. 
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	And if it has ears by which to hold it, then free the flesh fixed in them from every side with all the skill you can, and be ingenious, if it is not possible for the flesh to escape in the fracture of the ears and twisting them until it does escape.  
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you are performing the extraction of an arrow, wherever it may be, then use twisting of your hand with forceps on all sides until you make it come out, and with subtle finesse at the very end so that the arrow is not broken and its attraction and extraction become difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	And if you cannot get it out within an hour, then leave it for several days until what is around it becomes putrid.
